content:
Hi, for some project (unrelated to CT), I am studying real matrices LLL which satisfy

Laa≥0Lab≤0Laa≥∑b≠a∣Lab∣\begin{align*} L_{aa} &\ge 0 \\ L_{ab} &\le 0 \\ L_{aa} &\ge \sum_{b \ne a} |L_{ab}| \end{align*}Laa​Lab​Laa​​≥0≤0≥b=a∑​∣Lab​∣​

They look like laplacian matrices, the difference being that the third condition is an inequality instead of an equality. So I'm calling them super-laplacian matrices.

A laplacian matrix LLL is the matrix representation of the laplacian operator associated with a weighted graph. The vertices of the graph index the rows (and columns) of LLL, and there is an edge between two distinct vertices a,ba,ba,b whenever Lab<0L_{ab} < 0Lab​<0, the weight of this edge being ∣Lab∣|L_{ab}|∣Lab​∣. The quantity LaaL_{aa}Laa​ is equal to the sum of weights of all edges incident to aaa.

I think we can also interpret a super-laplacian matrix as a laplacian operator associated with some "open graph". Roughly speaking, such an open graph is a graph where some vertices are marked as "exterior" (the remaining vertices being "interior"). The interior vertices index the rows (and columns) of LLL. The difference Laa−∑b≠a∣Lab∣L_{aa} - \sum_{b\ne a} |L_{ab}|Laa​−∑b=a​∣Lab​∣, where bbb runs over interior vertices, accounts for the sum of weights of "boundary edges" connecting aaa to exterior vertices.

I came up with a more formal definition, but, given the ACT literature about open systems, I wonder if this has been studied already.

I don't understand one key sentence in your description. I'd hope that we have

Laa=∑b≠a∣Lab∣L_{aa} = \sum_{b\ne a} |L_{ab}|Laa​=∑b=a​∣Lab​∣

for all interior vertices aaa.

Anyway, I haven't seen this idea. It - or something similar, I haven't thought about it enough yet - looks very interesting. The spectral analysis of open graph Laplacians should be very cool if done right.

The fact that I haven't seen it doesn't mean very much, though! If it appeared in the structured cospan literature I should have seen it, but if it appeared in the graph theory literature I would never have seen it.

I think by "interior vertices" was meant all the vertices corresponding to rows and columns of the matrix and "exterior vertices" was meant to refer to the notional vertices connected to the "unattached" edges.

I think a "super-laplacian" matrix is indeed a matrix that's an on-diagonal block of a laplacian matrix, and you can always realize it this way by adding one row and column. You add La∗=−∑b≠∗∣Lab∣L_{a{*}} = - \sum_{b \ne {*}} |L_{ab}|La∗​=−∑b=∗​∣Lab​∣ and L∗b=0L_{{*}b} = 0L∗b​=0.

James Deikun said:

I think by "interior vertices" was meant all the vertices corresponding to rows and columns of the matrix and "exterior vertices" was meant to refer to the notional vertices connected to the "unattached" edges.

I think a "super-laplacian" matrix is indeed a matrix that's an on-diagonal block of a laplacian matrix, and you can always realize it this way by adding one row and column. You add La∗=−∑b≠∗∣Lab∣L_{a{*}} = - \sum_{b \ne {*}} |L_{ab}|La∗​=−∑b=∗​∣Lab​∣ and L∗b=0L_{{*}b} = 0L∗b​=0.

Yes that's right.

Here is an example
image.png

The usual laplacian of the whole graph is the matrix

Δ=abcxya3−1−1−10b−13−10−1c−1−1200x−10010y0−1001\Delta = \begin{array}{c|ccc|cc} & a & b & c & x & y \\ \hline a & 3 & -1 & -1 & -1 & 0 \\ b & -1 & 3 & -1 & 0 & -1 \\ c & -1 & -1 & 2 & 0 & 0 \\ \hline x & -1 & 0 & 0 & 1 & 0 \\ y & 0 & -1 & 0 & 0 & 1 \end{array}Δ=abcxy​a3−1−1−10​b−13−10−1​c−1−1200​x−10010​y0−1001​​

And if I "discard" the exterior vertices xxx and yyy, I obtain the submatrix

L=(3−1−1−13−1−1−12)L = \begin{pmatrix} 3 & -1 & -1 \\ -1 & 3 & -1 \\ -1 & -1 & 2 \end{pmatrix}L=​3−1−1​−13−1​−1−12​​

which is "super-laplacian".

John Baez said:

Anyway, I haven't seen this idea. It - or something similar, I haven't thought about it enough yet - looks very interesting. The spectral analysis of open graph Laplacians should be very cool if done right.

Oh thanks. Well, if this is new, I might give it a try. I have some preliminary results about a (baby) co/homology. But my current formal definition of open graphs feel clumsy. I'll have a look at structured (or decorated?) cospans.
Open graphs are one of the basic examples in structured cospan theory, so they appear in all introductions to structured cospans.
I explained a bit more the motivation behind my question in this topic
If this works it ought to (IMO) inform surgery on Riemannian manifolds. And vice versa. Like say (this is probably not the ideal reference) https://doi.org/10.1215/S0012-7094-06-13323-9

If anyone doesn't mind, I'll do like David Egolf, and use this thread to think out loud.

Base category G\mathbb{G}G

So, I reread the definition of a structured cospan. And before even using them, I need to figure out which category G\mathbb{G}G of graphs I want to use. I will need this category to be closed under finite colimit, and I'll probably need a left adjoint L:FinSet→GL : \text{FinSet} \to \mathbb{G}L:FinSet→G.

I'll start with informally stated requirements for the kind of graphs I need, and then I'll choose the most appropriate category G\mathbb{G}G. My problem is about heat propagation. Equivalently, I'm picturing random walks on graphs.

  • A graph has a set of vertices, that model the available positions for the walker.
  • The walker can hop from a vertex to another. There can be an edge eee from some vertex xxx to another vertex yyy.
  • The walker can traverse an edge forward, but also backward. For any edge eee from xxx to yyy, there is a reversed edge −e-e−e from yyy to xxx.
  • Each edge eee has a "thermal conductivity", i.e. a positive weight ω(e)>0\omega(e) > 0ω(e)>0.
  • A priori, there may be multiple edges from xxx to yyy. Maybe we will want, eventually, to merge these edges into one, and adding all their weights.

So, in my situation, I think a graph is a diagram of sets
image.png
where s,ts,ts,t denote the source and target map, iii is the involution that reverse edges, and ω\omegaω is the weight function.

The part that troubles me is the involution. It has to satisfy some conditions

  • i2=idi^2 = idi2=id
  • si=ts i = tsi=t, or equivalently s=tis = tis=ti
  • and perhaps i(e)≠ei(e) \ne ei(e)=e for all e∈Ee \in Ee∈E

This last condition is a bit weird, as it refers to elements of EEE.
The other part that troubles me is the weight ω\omegaω, because it refers directly to (0,∞)(0,\infty)(0,∞). I remember that attributes were handled a specific way in ACSets.

Ok, I re-read this blog post. I could present my schema as a profunctor SSS between the category consisting of E,VE,VE,V and i,s,ti,s,ti,s,t, and the singleton category, with single object (0,∞)(0,\infty)(0,∞). And then a graph would be an attributed c-set on this schema, i.e. some 222-cell etc. I guess this framework is useful to obtain general results about ac-sets, e.g., closure under colimits.
Anyway, I'll stay low-brow, and define my category G\mathbb{G}G explicitly.

An object GGG of G\mathbb{G}G is specified by

  • finite sets VVV and EEE
  • source and target functions s,t::E→Vs,t :: E \to Vs,t::E→V
  • an involution i:E→Ei : E \to Ei:E→E, such that si=tsi = tsi=t, ti=sti = sti=s, i2=idi^2 = idi2=id, and i(e)≠ei(e) \ne ei(e)=e for all e∈Ee \in Ee∈E
  • a weight function ω:E→(0,∞)\omega : E \to (0,\infty)ω:E→(0,∞)
That inequality will tend to prevent your category from having nice coequalizers.... I'd avoid that if I were you. (Equations are preserved by "quotient maps", inequalities not.)

Oh thanks. I'll follow your advice. So an object GGG of G\mathbb{G}G is specified by

  • finite sets VVV and EEE
  • source and target functions s,t::E→Vs,t :: E \to Vs,t::E→V
  • an involution i:E→Ei : E \to Ei:E→E, such that si=tsi = tsi=t, ti=sti = sti=s, i2=idi^2 = idi2=id
  • a weight function ω:E→(0,∞)\omega : E \to (0,\infty)ω:E→(0,∞)

For morphisms, I see two options.

  1. The most obvious one. A morphism from GGG to HHH is specified by functions f:V(G)→V(H)f : V(G) \to V(H)f:V(G)→V(H) and g:E(G)→E(H)g : E(G) \to E(H)g:E(G)→E(H) such that source and target functions are compatible (sg=fssg = fssg=fs, tg=fttg = fttg=ft), involutions are compatible (ig=giig = giig=gi), and weights are preserved (ωg=ω\omega g = \omegaωg=ω).

  2. Weights are accumulated. A morphism from GGG to HHH is specified by functions f,gf , gf,g as above, except for the preservation of weight. Instead,

ω(g(e))=∑e′ : g(e′)=g(e)ω(e′) \omega(g(e)) = \sum_{e' ~:~ g(e') = g(e)} \omega(e')ω(g(e))=e′ : g(e′)=g(e)∑​ω(e′)

I may need to think a bit more about my use case to decide which one is the best.

At the end, I would like to relate my graphs with laplacian matrices. From my small experience with computing graph laplacians, I noticed the following behaviour. Given a graph GGG, possibly with multiple edges with the same endpoints, it has laplacian matrix Δ\DeltaΔ. The off-diagonal entries of Δ\DeltaΔ aggregate the weights. Also, I can almost go the other way around: given a laplacian matrix Δ\DeltaΔ, I can build a graph (with at most one edge between any two distinct vertices) which has Δ\DeltaΔ as laplacian matrix.This situation feels like an adjunction.

So I'll stick with option 2 for my morphisms.

Now, to use the structured cospan machinery, it suffices that I

  1. check that G\mathbb{G}G has finite colimits
  2. define a left-adjoint functor L:FinSet→GL : \text{FinSet} \to \mathbb{G}L:FinSet→G

I believe 1 is true. For (finite) coproducts, I can do pointwise (finite) coproducts. This really amounts to putting a bunch of graphs next to each other. For coequalizers, consider two parallel morphisms a,ba,ba,b from GGG to HHH. I want to build a coequalizer graph QQQ. Let's define

V(Q)=V(H)/(a(x)=b(x))E(Q)=E(H)/(a(e)=b(e))\begin{align*} V(Q) &= V(H) / (a(x) = b(x)) \\ E(Q) &= E(H) / (a(e) = b(e)) \end{align*}V(Q)E(Q)​=V(H)/(a(x)=b(x))=E(H)/(a(e)=b(e))​

where (a(x)=b(x))(a(x) = b(x))(a(x)=b(x)) is a short-hand notation for the equivalence relation on V(H)V(H)V(H) generated by u≃vu \simeq vu≃v iff there exists x∈V(G)x \in V(G)x∈V(G) such that u=a(x)u = a(x)u=a(x) and v=b(x)v = b(x)v=b(x). And similarly for (a(e)=b(e))(a(e) = b(e))(a(e)=b(e)). The source and target maps can be defined consistenly on E(Q)E(Q)E(Q), the involution as well (thanks to John's advice).

The weight function is not so obvious, because of my choice of morphism

Actually, we have no choice. An edge ϵ∈E(Q)\epsilon \in E(Q)ϵ∈E(Q) is an equivalence class (subset of edges in E(H)E(H)E(H)). I define its weight as the sum of weights of its members, ω(ϵ)=∑e∈ϵω(e)\omega(\epsilon) = \sum_{e\in \epsilon} \omega(e)ω(ϵ)=∑e∈ϵ​ω(e). This is the only way to define it if I want the quotient map π:H→Q\pi : H \to Qπ:H→Q to satisfy the weight aggregation rule.
I'll skip the details on checking that QQQ, so defined, is indeed a coequalizer.

Alright, now, the functor L:FinSet→GL : \text{FinSet} \to \mathbb{G}L:FinSet→G. It maps a finite set VVV to the the graph with VVV as set of vertices, and empty set of edges. The right adjoint is the functor that maps a graph GGG to its set of vertices. Again, I'll skip checking the details (that they are functors, and adjoint to each other).

Open graphs

Finally, I obtain a symmetric monoidal double category Open(G)\text{Open}(\mathbb{G})Open(G) of open graphs.

  • its objects are finite sets
  • its vertical 111-morphisms are functions between finite sets
  • its horizontal 111-morphisms are cospans L(I)→G←L(J)L(I) \to G \leftarrow L(J)L(I)→G←L(J)
  • its 2-cells (I,G,J)→(K,H,L)(I, G, J) \to (K,H,L)(I,G,J)→(K,H,L) are triples (f,α,g)(f,\alpha,g)(f,α,g) with f:I→Kf : I \to Kf:I→K, α:G→H\alpha : G \to Hα:G→H, and g:J→Lg : J \to Lg:J→L such that the relevant squares commute.

Associated vector spaces

Ok, now the fun part, defining the laplacian. In algebraic graph theory, we can define the laplacian by considering the vector space C0=[V,R]C^0 = [V,\mathbb{R}]C0=[V,R] of functions on vertices, C1=[E,R]C^1 = [E, \mathbb{R}]C1=[E,R] of functions on edges, equipping them with the obvious inner products, defining the discrete differential δ:C0→C1\delta : C^0 \to C^1δ:C0→C1 by

δ(f):e↦f(s(e))−f(t(e))\delta(f) : e \mapsto f(s(e)) - f(t(e))δ(f):e↦f(s(e))−f(t(e))

and the laplacian Δ:C0→C0\Delta : C^0 \to C^0Δ:C0→C0 as

Δ=δ∗δ \Delta = \delta^* \deltaΔ=δ∗δ

where δ∗\delta^*δ∗ is the adjoint of δ\deltaδ.

Thanks to the categorical perspective, I want to try the following strategy:

  • A graph GGG is assigned a cochain complex 0→C0(G)→δC1(G)→00 \to C^0(G) \xrightarrow{\delta} C^1(G) \to 00→C0(G)δ​C1(G)→0.
  • I want to consider a category C≤1\mathbb{C}^{\le 1}C≤1 of cochain complexes (of length at most 111), with finite dimensional inner product spaces
  • Check that it has finite colimits, and I can define a left adjoint FinSet→C≤1\text{FinSet} \to \mathbb{C}^{\le 1}FinSet→C≤1
  • Build the sym mon double category Open(C≤1)\text{Open}(\mathbb{C}^{\le 1})Open(C≤1) of open cochain complexes
  • Have a monoidal double functor Open(G)→Open(C≤1)\text{Open}(\mathbb{G}) \to \text{Open}(\mathbb{C}^{\le 1})Open(G)→Open(C≤1)
Not sure, if this is the right approach. Even if I have an open cochain complex, how do I obtain a "laplacian"?

We usually get a graph Laplacian by making C0C^0C0 (resp. C1C^1C1) into inner product spaces such that vertices (resp. edges) form an orthonormal basis. This lets you define an operator d:C1(G)→C0(G)d: C^1(G) \to C^0(G)d:C1(G)→C0(G) by

⟨da,b⟩=⟨a,δb⟩ \langle d a, b \rangle = \langle a, \delta b \rangle ⟨da,b⟩=⟨a,δb⟩

(i.e. ddd is the adjoint operator of δ\deltaδ). Then we get a Laplacian on C0(G)C^0(G)C0(G) by Δ=dδ \Delta = d \deltaΔ=dδ and one on C1(G)C^1(G)C1(G) by taking δd\delta dδd.
By the way, the people I know write ddd for your δ\deltaδ and ∂\partial∂ for what I just called ddd.

Yes. This gives me another idea. So we want define inner product spaces C0(G)C^0(G)C0(G) and C1(G)C^1(G)C1(G), and a linear map d:C0(G)→C1(G)d : C^0(G) \to C^1(G)d:C0(G)→C1(G) when GGG is an open graph, i.e. a horizontal 1-morphism in Open(G)\text{Open}(\mathbb{G})Open(G).

So, maybe, we want to define symmetric monoidal double functors C0,C1:Open(G)→UC^0, C^1 : \text{Open}(\mathbb{G}) \to \mathbb{U}C0,C1:Open(G)→U into a well-chosen sym mon double category U\mathbb{U}U, and a transformation d:C0⇒C1d: C^0 \Rightarrow C^1d:C0⇒C1 that satisfy some good properties.

Defining U=Open(V)\mathbb{U} = \text{Open}(\mathbb{V})U=Open(V)

I will try to define U\mathbb{U}U using the structured cospan construction, U=Open(V)\mathbb{U} = \text{Open}(\mathbb{V})U=Open(V).

Let's try with V\mathbb{V}V the category specified by:

  • objects: finite dimensional inner product spaces
  • morphisms: linear maps

I claim V\mathbb{V}V is closed under finite colimits. Indeed, Orthogonal direct sums provide coproducts. Cokernel of f:A→Bf : A \to Bf:A→B is provided by the projection on the orthogonal complement of the image of fff in BBB.

Now, I want to define a functor L:FinSet→VL : \text{FinSet} \to \mathbb{V}L:FinSet→V that preserve finite colimits.

Given a finite set XXX, I define L(X)L(X)L(X) to be the free vector space equipped with the unique inner product that makes XXX an orthonormal basis.

I don't think LLL is a left adjoint, because, intuitively, the right adjoint would need to pick an orthonormal basis. So I'll check directly if LLL preserve finite colimits.

It seems clear to me that LLL preserve finite coproducts, so I'll focus on coequalizers.
Consider two parallel functions f,g:X→Yf,g : X \to Yf,g:X→Y between finite sets, and q:Y→Qq : Y \to Qq:Y→Q their coequalizer.
image.png

We have to check that the linear map Lq:L(Y)→L(Q)Lq : L(Y) \to L(Q)Lq:L(Y)→L(Q) is a cokernel of h=L(f)−L(g)h = L(f) - L(g)h=L(f)−L(g).

LqLqLq is a cokernel

Consider the linear map π:L(Y)→L(Y)\pi : L(Y) \to L(Y)π:L(Y)→L(Y) defined, for all y∈Yy \in Yy∈Y,

π(y)=1∣q(y)∣∑y′∈q(y)y′\pi (y) = \frac{1}{|q(y)|} \sum_{y' \in q(y)} y'π(y)=∣q(y)∣1​y′∈q(y)∑​y′

This map is the orthogonal projection on the orthogonal complement (Im(f−g))⊥(\text{Im}(f - g))^\bot(Im(f−g))⊥. This makes π\piπ a cokernel of f−gf - gf−g.

π\piπ is a cokernel of f−gf - gf−g

First, I claim π\piπ is an orthogonal projection.
As an averaging operator, it is idempotent, π2=π\pi^2 = \piπ2=π. Also, for any y,z∈Yy,z \in Yy,z∈Y,

⟨z,π(y)⟩=1∣q(y)∣∑y′∈q(y)⟨z,y′⟩={1q(y)if q(y)=q(z)0otherwise=⟨π(z),y⟩\begin{align*} \langle z, \pi(y) \rangle &= \frac{1}{|q(y)|} \sum_{y' \in q(y)} \langle z, y' \rangle \\ &= \begin{cases} \frac{1}{q(y)} &\text{if } q(y) = q(z) \\ 0 &\text{otherwise} \end{cases}\\ &= \langle \pi(z), y \rangle \end{align*}⟨z,π(y)⟩​=∣q(y)∣1​y′∈q(y)∑​⟨z,y′⟩={q(y)1​0​if q(y)=q(z)otherwise​=⟨π(z),y⟩​

Hence, π\piπ is an orthogonal projection.

Moreover, for any x∈Xx \in Xx∈X and y∈Yy \in Yy∈Y, a direct calculation shows that

⟨f(x)−g(x),π(y)⟩=0\langle f(x) - g(x), \pi(y) \rangle = 0⟨f(x)−g(x),π(y)⟩=0

On the other hand, if there exists some z∈Yz \in Yz∈Y, such that ⟨z,f(x)−g(x)⟩=0\langle z, f(x) - g(x) \rangle = 0⟨z,f(x)−g(x)⟩=0 for all x∈Xx \in Xx∈X,
then, for all y∈Yy \in Yy∈Y,

⟨(1−π)z,y⟩=⟨z,(1−π)y⟩=1∣q(y)∣∑y′∈q(y)⟨z,y−y′⟩=0\begin{align*} \langle (1 - \pi) z, y \rangle &= \langle z, (1 - \pi) y \rangle \\ &= \frac{1}{|q(y)|} \sum_{y' \in q(y)} \langle z, y - y' \rangle \\ &= 0 \end{align*}⟨(1−π)z,y⟩​=⟨z,(1−π)y⟩=∣q(y)∣1​y′∈q(y)∑​⟨z,y−y′⟩=0​

I.e., z=π(z)z = \pi(z)z=π(z). We conclude that π\piπ is the (orthogonal) projection on (Im(f−g))⊥(\text{Im}(f-g))^\bot(Im(f−g))⊥.

Now, I define an isomorphism between L(Q)L(Q)L(Q) and Im(f−g)⊥\text{Im}(f-g)^\botIm(f−g)⊥.
Each equivalence class c∈Qc \in Qc∈Q on YYY, is sent to

γ(c)=1∣c∣∑y∈cy\gamma(c) = \frac{1}{|c|} \sum_{y\in c} yγ(c)=∣c∣1​y∈c∑​y

This defines a linear map γ:L(Q)→Im(f−g)⊥\gamma : L(Q) \to \text{Im}(f-g)^\bot γ:L(Q)→Im(f−g)⊥. By construction,

⟨γ(c),γ(c′)⟩={1∣c∣if c=c′0otherwise\langle \gamma(c), \gamma(c') \rangle = \begin{cases} \frac{1}{|c|} &\text{if } c = c' \\ 0 &\text{otherwise} \end{cases}⟨γ(c),γ(c′)⟩={∣c∣1​0​if c=c′otherwise​

and

γ⋅Lq=π\gamma \cdot Lq = \piγ⋅Lq=π

This implies

⟨π(y),π(y′)⟩={1∣q(y)∣if q(y)=q(y′)0if q(y)≠q(y′)\langle \pi(y), \pi(y') \rangle = \begin{cases} \frac{1}{|q(y)|} &\text{if } q(y) = q(y') \\ 0 &\text{if } q(y) \ne q(y') \end{cases}⟨π(y),π(y′)⟩={∣q(y)∣1​0​if q(y)=q(y′)if q(y)=q(y′)​

which shows that the dimension of Im(f−g)⊥\text{Im}(f-g)^\botIm(f−g)⊥ is ∣Q∣|Q|∣Q∣.
Therefore, γ\gammaγ is an isomorphism, and Lq=γ−1πLq = \gamma^{-1} \piLq=γ−1π is also a cokernel of f−gf - gf−g.

We conclude that LLL preserves finite colimits.

Wrapping everything up, the structured cospan construction gives a sym monoidal double
category U=Open(V)\mathbb{U} = \text{Open}(\mathbb{V})U=Open(V). Concretely,

  • objects: finite sets
  • vertical 1-morphisms: functions between finite sets
  • horizontal 1-morphisms: cospan L(X)→V←L(Y)L(X) \to V \leftarrow L(Y)L(X)→V←L(Y) of finite dimensional inner product vector spaces
  • 2-cells from (X,V,Y)(X,V,Y)(X,V,Y) to (X′,V′,Y′)(X',V',Y')(X′,V′,Y′): triple (f,α,g)(f, \alpha, g)(f,α,g) with functions f:X→X′f : X \to X'f:X→X′, g:Y→Y′g : Y \to Y'g:Y→Y′, and linear map α:V→V′\alpha : V \to V'α:V→V′ such that the obvious squares commute.

Functor C0C^0C0

I want to define a (sym mon double) functor C0:Open(G)→Open(V)C^0 : \text{Open}(\mathbb{G}) \to \text{Open}(\mathbb{V})C0:Open(G)→Open(V).
Both double categories have the same vertical category FinSet\text{FinSet}FinSet, so the object and vertical parts of C0C^0C0 are clear.

Focus on the horizontal part. Consider an open graph (X,G,Y)(X,G,Y)(X,G,Y), i.e. a cospan in G\mathbb{G}G

L(X)→G←L(Y)L(X) \to G \leftarrow L(Y)L(X)→G←L(Y)

The core idea is to send a graph H∈GH \in \mathbb{G}H∈G to the vector space of real functions on the vertices of HHH, equipped with the obvious inner product ⟨f,g⟩=∑vf(v)g(v)\langle f, g \rangle = \sum_v f(v) g(v)⟨f,g⟩=∑v​f(v)g(v). If ϕ:H→K\phi : H \to Kϕ:H→K is morphism in G\mathbb{G}G, the linear map ψ=C0ϕ:C0K→C0H\psi = C^0 \phi : C^0 K \to C^0 Hψ=C0ϕ:C0K→C0H is defined, for all f∈C0Kf \in C^0 Kf∈C0K

ψ(f):(v∈V(H))→f(ϕ(v))\psi(f) : (v \in V(H)) \to f( \phi(v) )ψ(f):(v∈V(H))→f(ϕ(v))

A harmonic morphism G→HG \to HG→H is about "locally relating diffusion (or random walks) on the two spaces". Or, pulling back a random walk on HHH to a random walk on GGG.

Now, when composing open graphs (horizontally), we are gluing two spaces together along a specified subspace. But there must be a condition on the kinds of gluing I want, otherwise my harmonic morphisms won't go through.

Right. This kind of issue shows up in a lot of places. In the study of PDE we don't usually demand that functions are harmonic on the boundary: instead, we impose boundary conditions. In TQFT, we don't glue smooth manifolds together along a boundary, because the result wouldn't be smooth: instead we thicken the boundary up to a 'collar' and glue the collars together.

Both issues would show up if one were trying to cook up a (double) category where the morphisms M:S→TM : S \to TM:S→T are something like smooth manifolds MMM with boundary ∂M=S∪T\partial M = S \cup T∂M=S∪T equipped with harmonic functions f:M→Rf: M \to \mathbb{R}f:M→R. That sounds like something people studying the Laplace equation would like to do - but they'd instantly run into issues like you're hitting. So they'd try to use tricks to deal with these issues.

I think I found a trick. I'll define the category FinSetΔ\text{FinSet}_\DeltaFinSetΔ​ of finite sets, with "harmonic functions".

Objects are finite sets. And a "harmonic function" from XXX to YYY is a pair (f,deg⁡f)(f, \deg_f)(f,degf​) where f:X→Yf : X \to Yf:X→Y is a usual function, and deg⁡f:X→(0,∞)\deg_f : X \to (0,\infty)degf​:X→(0,∞) is a function. I am interpreting deg⁡f\deg_fdegf​ as the degree function of fff, although there is no laplacian to work with.

Composition of f:X→Yf : X \to Yf:X→Y and g:Y→Zg : Y \to Zg:Y→Z is given by the usual function composition for the function part, and its degree by a "chain rule"

deg⁡gf(x)=deg⁡g(f(x))⋅deg⁡f(x)\deg_{gf}(x) = \deg_g(f(x)) \cdot \deg_f(x)deggf​(x)=degg​(f(x))⋅degf​(x)

  • a target cospan I→H←JI \to H \leftarrow JI→H←J, where, again, I,JI,JI,J are finite sets and HHH a graph

  • a harmonic graph morphism α:G→H\alpha : G \to Hα:G→H

such that α\alphaα matches (f,deg⁡f)(f,\deg_f)(f,degf​) on XXX, and (g,deg⁡g)(g,\deg_g)(g,degg​) on YYY, both with respect to vertices, and the degrees. I.e., for all x∈Xx \in Xx∈X and y∈Yy\in Yy∈Y,

α(x)=f(x), deg⁡α(x)=deg⁡f(x)α(y)=g(y), deg⁡α(y)=deg⁡g(y)\begin{align*} \alpha(x) = f(x), &~ \deg_\alpha(x) = \deg_f(x) \\ \alpha(y) = g(y), &~ \deg_\alpha(y) = \deg_g(y) \end{align*}α(x)=f(x),α(y)=g(y),​ degα​(x)=degf​(x) degα​(y)=degg​(y)​

I've not been following in any kind of detail, so I hope it's okay to ask a basic question!

When I think of composing via pushouts, I think of working with objects where each object has an "input" and an "output". And I have the idea that the output of one object needs to match the input of the other: I think that matching input/output is what we're gluing along in the pushout. So then when we're done, we end up with a glued together object having the input of one object and the output of the other.

But in this case of graphs with "interior" and "exterior" vertices it does not immediately seem to me like there is an input and output. It's more like there is an "interface" of exterior vertices which can be glued (in only certain ways, I assume, to satisfy the description in the associated super-laplacian matrix?) to other interfaces.

So does it really make sense to compose cospans using pushouts in this case, where seemingly our objects don't come with clear "inputs" and "outputs"? I don't know what the standard kind of tool is to glue together things with interfaces, if the interfaces aren't necessarily nicely described in terms of an "input" part and an "output" part.

I also wanted to say: I find the first idea you described above quite intriguing! It seems to me that this "super-laplacian" matrix describes a way to "zoom in" on part of a graph, and get a subgraph together with some partial information about how it connects to the rest of the graph.

Studying situations where we have only partial information about how the part relates to the whole (or other parts) sounds interesting to me. Or from a bit of a different angle, I'm interested in how to stitch together things where we have some partially specifying restriction on how to do so. (For example, in medical imaging it is common to combine local or low-quality reconstructions to form a more complete or higher-quality one.)
Pushing out things that hae any kind of part in common is a typical practice; it doesn't have to be "input" on one side and "output" on the other, though it can.

James Deikun said:

Pushing out things that hae any kind of part in common is a typical practice; it doesn't have to be "input" on one side and "output" on the other, though it can.

That makes sense! I guess it seems to me that there could be a certain amount of arbitrary "directionality" involved in this case, though, if one is making a category where the morphisms are cospans. We need a source and target for each cospan, but if the two feet of the cospan are on "equal footing" (as opposed to the case where one foot is the "input" and one is the "output" for some application of interest) deciding which foot is the source and which is the target sounds a bit unsatisfying. But maybe this is fine in practice!
Oh! I suppose one way to avoid making this unsatisfying choice would just be to have two morphisms for each cospan, one for each choice of source and target.

More generally, if one can use this cospan approach to glue together things without "inputs" and "outputs" (instead having just an interface) by deciding for the moment which part of the interface should act as an "input" and which part of the interface should act as an "output" - then that's very cool! That sounds pretty powerful.

Yeah, if you have an electrical circuit made of wires with resistors, capacitors and inductors on them, with some loose wires hanging out, the circuit doesn't know which wires you're considering "inputs" and which you're considering "outputs". It merely sets up a relation between the voltages and currents on these loose wires. And you can attach one circuit to another without caring what part of the interface is the "input" and what part is the "output".

This was the first example my student Brendan Fong did back around 2015 when he invented the theory of "decorated cospans" (cospans where the apex is equipped with some extra structure). Later my students and I handled Markov processes this way, and then Petri nets, and then stock-flow models for epidemiology, and so on. In all these examples the division of the interface into two parts, "input" and "output", is purely conventional. We can also divide the interface into more parts using a "multicospan"... or just one part.... depending on what's convenient.

The new DOTS (double operadic theory of systems) formalism that Topos is using for their ARIA grant for safeguarded AI uses these ideas and others - but one move they make is to always use just one interface. It turns out they can get away with that.
@David Egolf (he/him) Just to add to what James and John said, an interesting feature of such structures is that you can easily flip inputs and outputs. And I think dagger categories formalize this.

Adding free wires

I just noticed that I was lacking an identity in my (horizontal) category of open graphs. I think it suffices to add "free wires" to my open graph, i.e. edge-like things that are not incident to any vertex. Or, to put it another way, a pairing of input and output half-edges. I want these wires just to transport currents.

With this electric picture in mind, it is tempting to think about magnetism as well. Instead of a graph, we would have a simplicial complex with triangular faces. On these triangular faces would live magnetic fluxes, which would induce loopy currents (Faraday's law). But let's leave that for future investigations.

As you may know, Brendan Fong and I did a study of open electric circuits where a lot of the deeper work started when we tried to get identity morphisms. You can always take a [[semicategory]] and formally throw in identities, but we didn't want to do that.
I was actually browsing through your work. Thank you for pointing out the paper!

To get identities in a category where morphisms are something like "graphs with half-edges", Joachim Kock goes further and allows what some people call "passing edges". These are edges that have neither a source nor target vertex.... they just pass through. The idea is that if you compose such a passing edge

It turns out to be quite easy to define "undirected graphs with half-edges and passing edges". Kock and Joyal call them Feynman graphs and define them in Section 2 of Feynman graphs, and nerve theorem for compact symmetric multicategories (extended abstract)

Oh this is very interesting!

From what I understood, they do not consider Feynman graphs directly as morphisms in a category.
Instead, it seems that they consider a Feynman graph with nnn ports as a pattern of composition to obtain a nnn-ary operation.

Sligthly more formally

  • They consider the category Gr0Gr_0Gr0​ of Feynman graphs with étale maps
  • Each Feynman graph has an interface, expressed as a finite set of (say nnn) ports
  • Then, define graphical species as sheaves on Gr0Gr_0Gr0​, or equivalently as presheaves on a full subcategory of elementary graphs (they look like corollas)
  • Then, define a monad on the category of graphical species
  • Finally, define "compact symmetric multicategories" as the algebras of this monad

So their formulation leans more on the "unbiased/non-directional" way of composing, in contrast with, e.g., the cospan construction which is more on the "directional" side (as noticed by @David Egolf (he/him) earlier)

I think the formal definition of Feynman graphs may be what I need. Interestingly, they consider étale maps, whereas I considered, earlier, harmonious maps. I may be wrong, but it seems that étale maps are also harmonious maps.

So I dig a bit more into the literature, and found an interesting paper which discusses pseudo-inverse of laplacians and simplices. The part that interests me is their Property 5.

Consider a usual graph GGG. Partition the vertices VG=VH⊔VKV_G = V_H \sqcup V_KVG​=VH​⊔VK​, and let HHH and KKK be the corresponding (full) subgraphs. Then the graph laplacian of GGG can be written, in matrix form, as

ΔG=(ΔH−B−B⊤ΔK)\Delta_G = \begin{pmatrix} \Delta_H & -B \\ -B^\top & \Delta_K \end{pmatrix}ΔG​=(ΔH​−B⊤​−BΔK​​)

Consider the Schur complement

Δ^H=ΔH−BΔK−1B⊤\widehat{\Delta}_H = \Delta_H - B \Delta_K^{-1} B^\topΔH​=ΔH​−BΔK−1​B⊤

Then Δ^H\widehat{\Delta}_HΔH​ is a laplacian matrix.

What I find interesting is:

  • ΔH\Delta_HΔH​ is a super-laplacian matrix
  • It is as if taking the Schur complement "integrates out" the "surrounding graph" KKK.

I haven't read the conversation in full detail, but maybe this would be interesting to you. We use the Schur complement in precisely this way to remove internal vertices from our labelled graphs in order to obtain a normal form for the compact closed category affine Lagrangian relations:

https://arxiv.org/pdf/2401.07914#proposition.35

This subsumes the star-mesh transformations of electrical circuits as well as the local complementation and pivoting of stabiliser quantum states.
